intro: Tragacantha genistoides, commonly known as the Persian broom, is a flowering plant native to the Middle East and parts of Central Asia. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its slender, branching stems and small yellow flowers. The plant produces a unique resinous gum, which has been historically used in traditional medicine and as a natural adhesive. Its leaves are trifoliate, consisting of three oval-shaped leaflets, and it thrives in arid and semi-arid environments. Tragacantha genistoides is also valued for its ornamental appeal and ecological benefits in sandy soils.
